title: 105_hr3748
content: The "FEC Reauthorization Act of 1998" authorizes appropriations for the Federal Election Commission for fiscal year 1999, with specific allocations for enforcement procedures and prevention of unnecessary dismissal of enforcement actions. Additionally, the Act addresses the appointment and service of the staff director and general counsel of the Commission. The "FEC Reauthorization Act of 1998" amends the appointment and term limits for the staff director and general counsel of the Federal Election Commission, requiring an affirmative vote of 4 members for appointment and limiting consecutive terms to 4 years. The amendment applies to individuals serving in these roles on or after January 1, 1999. The "FEC Reauthorization Act of 1998" amends the appointment and term limits for the staff director and general counsel of the Federal Election Commission. An individual appointed to fill a vacancy must serve only the unexpired term of their predecessor and cannot continue in any capacity after their term expires unless reappointed. SEC. 4. ALTERNATIVE PROCEDURES FOR IMPOSITION OF PENALTIES FOR REPORTING VIOLATIONS. Section 309(a)(4) of the Federal Election Campaign Act of 1971 is amended to allow the Commission to find violations related to reporting of receipts or disbursements and impose civil money penalties based on a schedule of penalties established by the Commission. The Commission may impose civil money penalties for violations, considering factors like the violation amount and past violations. Written notice and opportunity for a hearing are required before an adverse determination. Review of the determination can be sought in a district court within 30 days. The amendments made by this section apply to violations occurring on or after January 1, 1999. SEC. 5. STANDARD FOR INITIATION OF ACTIONS BY FEC. The Federal Election Campaign Act is amended to require the general counsel of the Commission to provide a recommendation within 90 days after a complaint is filed, regarding whether there is sufficient reason to investigate any alleged violation. If the Commission determines there is sufficient reason by an affirmative vote of 4 members, an investigation will be initiated. The Revenue Code of 1986 amendment requires the Commission to notify individuals of alleged violations, investigate them, and the effective date is January 1, 1999 for complaints filed after that date.
